article.title: Cosmological production of ultralight dark matter axions

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the parameter \'n\' in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The axion decay constant.
The initial misalignment angle.
The sharpness of the phase transition in the axion mass.
The Hubble parameter at the end of inflation.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Scenario A (below the line fa = H1/(2π)), what determines the amount of mass density in PNG bosons?
choices: The axion decay constant, fa.
The Hubble parameter at the end of inflation, H1.
Both the axion decay constant and the Hubble parameter at the end of inflation.
None of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the yellow shaded area in Figure 2 represent?
choices: Regions excluded by isocurvature perturbations.
Regions excluded by tensor modes.
Regions excluded by relic density observations.
Astrophyiscal bounds from the coupling to photons.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the parametrization in Equation (2)?
choices: To determine the exact value of the axion mass at all temperatures.
To model the transition of the axion mass from effectively massless to its zero-temperature value.
To calculate the Hubble parameter at the end of inflation.
To define the initial misalignment angle.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the function Fr(θi, fa, n) in Equation (18) represent?
choices: The size of the Hubble horizon at the onset of field oscillations.
The amplitude of isocurvature perturbations.
The combined effect of anharmonicities and T-dependent mass on the cut-off scale.
The contribution of the misaligned vacuum to the energy density.
